awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Non-Commutative Cryptography from Hard Learning Problems: Theory and Practice
awd_abstract_narration:
The resiliency of much of the modern information technology ecosystem is predicated on the strength of the cryptographic constructions at its core. Uncovering new intractable problems suitable for cryptosystem design enhances the robustness of the overall infrastructure to breakthroughs like the development of quantum computers or unforeseen cryptanalytic advances against any specific computational problem. This project develops the theory and practice of a novel approach to cryptography based on a class of learning problems over non-commutative groups, known collectively as Learning Homomorphisms with Noise (LHN). The appeal of non-commutative groups as a source of cryptographic hardness, due in part to the absence of significant quantum algorithms for this setting, has long been recognized, but isolating suitable intractability assumptions has proven elusive.

The project explores four main threads: (1) designing efficient cryptographic constructions based on the hardness of LHN; (2) establishing evidence of the intractability of the underlying learning problems, especially against quantum computing; (3) building a software library to manipulate instances of these learning problems efficiently, and evaluating the performance of learning-based non-commutative cryptography; and (4) exploring additional LHN variants to overcome any limitation encountered in the execution of the other threads. By diversifying the premises on which to base cryptography and creating training opportunities in information security for tomorrow's workforce, this project will strengthen a critical part of the modern information technology infrastructure.

por.por_cntn:
OVERVIEW

The resiliency of most modern cryptographic constructions hinges with mathematical strength on the  intractability of certain computational problems.  The landscape of (conjectured) intractable problems employed in much existing cryptographic literature enjoys little diversity, creating the risk that a handful of cryptoanalytic breakthroughs might invalidate large swaths of that landscape at once.  This CAREER project contributed to addressing this need by making quantifiable advances in the understanding of the suitability of a certain type of learning problems over a class of combinatorial groups (_Burnside Groups of Exponent Three_) as an *efficient* and *plausible* source of computational intractability for cryptographic applications.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

This CAREER project contributed to the theory and practice of a new approach to cryptography based on the computational hardness of certain learning problems over non-commutative groups, known collectively as Learning Burnside Homomorphisms with Noise.  A key advantage of the approach pursued in this project is that it molds an established flavor of conjecturably intractable learning problems over a branch of mathematics for which quantum computing is not known to bring about substantial advantages over classical algorithms.  While teasing out rigorous mathematical evidence to the quantum-resistance of the proposed intractability assumptions has proven elusive, it remains promising ground for future work in the area.

The research carried out in the context of this project has shed new light on the computational properties of free Burnside groups of exponent 3 on n generators, which can be thought of as a generalization of the n-dimensional vector space over the field of three element (Z_3^n) that results from forgoing commutativity.  Specifically, the PI and his collaborators have devised several data structures and algorithms for the efficient representation and manipulation of Burnside elements, and are building a cryptographic software library that will be made publicly available so as to foster further research on this non-commutative combinatorial groups by the community at large.

BROADER IMPACTS

Information technology is central to modern societies, and most approaches to securing information depend critically on cryptographic mechanisms. By diversifying the premises on which cryptographic constructions are based, this CAREER project has contributed to enhancing the robustness of a our cyber-infrastructure.

This CAREER project has also contributed to the development of new educational units on cryptographic software to be incorporated in existing security courses at Stevens Institute of Technology that will be made available online to the general public through the webpage of the PI.

Funding from this project has supported graduate research training for: one PhD student; one Engineer student; and one Master student.
